content: Consider why you are quitting methadone. If you are taking methadone as a maintenance drug to aid in recovering from an opiate addiction, you are probably better off sticking with it. Methadone maintenance has no significant negative health effects, and patients who remain on methadone show gradual but steady improvements in health and functioning, while those who quit worsen in both aspects and have a much higher tendency to relapse into opiate use. [2] Speak with an addiction specialist. You will need both medical and psychological support to get off of methadone. It is important to note that not all doctors are able to prescribe withdrawal drugs like suboxone, because it requires a special training and approval from the government, such as the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) in the Unites States. Physicians with the proper training can tailor a withdrawal program to suit your needs and prescribe appropriate withdrawal drugs. Set up a support network of friends and family. Quitting methadone is not easy. You will suffer withdrawal symptoms, and you will need to either carefully reduce your methadone intake over time or take medications regularly to substitute for methadone. Especially if you are quitting in an out-patient setting, it is extremely helpful to have friends and family who can hold you accountable and remind you to stay on course. Do not try to quit “cold turkey. ” The symptoms of methadone withdrawal are painful enough that quitting suddenly is simply not realistic. They typically begin within 30 hours of last methadone exposure and include: [3] [4] Early symptoms: agitation, anxiety, muscle aches, insomnia, runny nose, sweating, and yawning Late symptoms: abdominal cramping, diarrhea, dilated pupils, goose bumps, nausea, vomiting Be aware that quitting is a long-term process. Methadone withdrawal symptoms typically begin between 24 – 36 hours after the last dose and peak between 96 and 144 hours. While the detox process is usually considered over after five to seven days, milder symptoms may last for weeks, and “abstinence syndrome” — including unease, fatigue, insomnia, and irritability — can last for up to eight months. [5] Sign up with an inpatient program if possible. Inpatient programs take less time and are up to four times as effective at achieving complete withdrawal. [6] Check here to find a clinic near you. Reduce methadone use gradually. There are two methods typically used: tapering the amount of methadone used or substituting buprenorphine and tapering or maintaining. Long-term maintenance with buprenorphine, accompanied by counseling and support groups, has been shown to produce the best rate of success. [7] Rapid detox programs using naltrexone to induce withdrawal can shorten peak withdrawal symptoms to two to three days, but there is no evidence regarding the rates of long-term abstinence for such programs. [8] Rapid detox under anesthesia should be avoided. It does not improve long-term results and carries a significant risk of death due to pulmonary edema (fluid in the lungs). [9] Maintenance on naltrexone is another option. It blocks the nerve receptors that opiates use, meaning that users of naltrexone will be unable to get high on opiates; however, relapse rates are very high for naltrexone treatments. Taper with methadone. There are two methods of tapering: a relatively quick method and a more recently prescribed long term method. In both cases, clonidine is often given to help reduce the symptoms of withdrawal. The more traditional tapering method usually takes five to seven weeks. Patients first rapidly reduce their use to 30 mg per day before beginning tapering at a typical rate of 5 mg per week. [10] Some clinics now recommend a more drawn-out tapering over six months to a year. The dose is reduced by 5 mg every three to 14 days, and then even more slowly after reaching 20 mg. [11] Maintain or taper with buprenorphine-naxolone (Subuxone). Buprenorphine maintenance has been shown to be more effective than simply quitting methadone, while tapering with buprenoprhine is just as effective as tapering with methadone, and helps withdrawal symptoms to fade more quickly. [12] Patients must first reduce their methadone use to 40 mg/day for a week before beginning to substitute buprenorphine for methadone. Starting 36 hours after the last dose of methadone, the oral drug buprenorphine can be used to reduce symptoms of withdrawal. [13] Initial dose is 2 – 4 mg of buprenorphine. If that is tolerated, a second 2 – 4 mg does is given an hour later, and then 4 mg six to eight hours later, for a total day one dose of 8 –12 mg. A dose of 12 – 16 mg is reached by day two or three and should suppress most symptoms of withdrawal from methadone, with additional symptoms treated by clonidine. Once the patient’s withdrawal symptoms are stabilized, buprenorphine can be continued as a long-term maintenance drug, or can be tapered off over two to three weeks. Once you have been weaned off methadone, your primary care provider may also be able to prescribe another form of buprenorphine (Butrans) which is available in patch or oral form. Get counseling. Your doctor or the clinic you are visiting will be able to put you in touch with an experienced opiate-withdrawal counselor. Whether it is one-on-one, group, or in a family setting, counseling in conjunction with buprenorphine maintenance or detox has been shown to be much more effective than maintenance or detox alone. [14] Join a support group. Support groups like Narcotics Anonymous or SMART Recovery can be extremely helpful for the recovering patient. One study found that recovering patients attending NA and AA programs had an 81% abstinence rate, compared to a 26% abstinence rate among non-attendees. [15] Don't force yourself to go through the pain of methadone withdrawal alone. There are thousands of other recovering patients just like you, who can not only give you advice and support, but who draw inspiration from you. Use clonidine or lofexidine to treat lingering withdrawal symptoms. [16] While clonidine is not as effective as buprenorphine during detox, it is useful in reducing lingering flu-like symptoms such as anxiety, agitation, muscle aches, sweating, runny nose, and cramping, all of which may last up to eight months. Lofexidine is a drug with a similar pathway, recently approved in the UK, which can reduce symptoms with fewer side effects. [17] Ask your doctor about using trazodone, zaleplon or zolpidem to treat insomnia. Insomnia is a common symptom of withdrawal from methadone. Zaleplon and zolpidem work like benzodiazepines such as clonazepam, but without the same withdrawal symptoms. [18] Trazodone is an antidepressant that regulates serotonin levels, thereby aiding sleep. [19] Treat the other lingering symptoms of withdrawal. Muscle cramps, diarrhea, nausea, and flu-like symptoms are most likely during detox, but such symptoms can linger for weeks. Aches and diarrhea can be treated with over-the-counter medications such as ibuprofen (Advil) and bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol). Your doctor may prescribe prochlorperazine (Compazine) or ondansetron (Zofran) for nausea. [20]

<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Withdraw-from-Methadone">How to Withdraw from Methadone</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Janice Litza, MD</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Deciding_to_Quit_Methadone_sub" id="">Deciding to Quit Methadone</a>

</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=janicelitza%2Cmd#janicelitza%2Cmd">Janice Litza, MD</a>. Dr. Litza is a Board Certified Family Medicine Physician in Wisconsin. She is a practicing Physician and taught as a Clinical Professor for 13 years, after receiving her MD from the University of Wisconsin-Madison School of Medicine and Public Health in 1998.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">20 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Methadone is a synthetic opiate occasionally prescribed for chronic pain, but more often used to wean patients off of opiates like heroin. For most patients, a lifelong course of methadone treatment, or maintenance therapy, is necessary to prevent relapse and return to heroin use.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> It is helpful to think of methadone for heroin addicts as the equivalent of insulin for diabetics. Nevertheless, some patients will wish to cease using methadone. To do so, you will need to consult your doctor, seek support from a therapist and/or support group, and quit gradually, using doctor-prescribed drugs to minimize the symptoms of withdrawal.</p>
<br/><p><i>Note: Any withdrawal program should be supervised by a suitably qualified professional. This article offers general guidance and is not a substitute for professional treatment.</i></p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Deciding_to_Quit_Methadone_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Deciding_to_Quit_Methadone">Deciding to Quit Methadone</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-1-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-1-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_9a8f23ab65" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9a8f23ab65')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider why you are quitting methadone.</b> If you are taking methadone as a maintenance drug to aid in recovering from an opiate addiction, you are probably better off sticking with it. Methadone maintenance has no significant negative health effects, and patients who remain on methadone show gradual but steady improvements in health and functioning, while those who quit worsen in both aspects and have a much higher tendency to relapse into opiate use.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-2-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-2-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7d/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_5e9e243762" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5e9e243762')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7d/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Speak with an addiction specialist.</b> You will need both medical and psychological support to get off of methadone. It is important to note that not all doctors are able to prescribe withdrawal drugs like suboxone, because it requires a special training and approval from the government, such as the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) in the Unites States. Physicians with the proper training can tailor a withdrawal program to suit your needs and prescribe appropriate withdrawal drugs.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-3-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-3-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/86/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_404675cd83" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_404675cd83')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/86/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Set up a support network of friends and family.</b> Quitting methadone is not easy. You will suffer withdrawal symptoms, and you will need to either carefully reduce your methadone intake over time or take medications regularly to substitute for methadone. Especially if you are quitting in an out-patient setting, it is extremely helpful to have friends and family who can hold you accountable and remind you to stay on course.

</div>

</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Getting_off_Methadone_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Getting_off_Methadone">Getting off Methadone</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b2/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_51185de5b0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_51185de5b0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b2/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do not try to quit “cold turkey.</b><b>”</b> The symptoms of methadone withdrawal are painful enough that quitting suddenly is simply not realistic. They typically begin within 30 hours of last methadone exposure and include:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Early symptoms: agitation, anxiety, muscle aches, insomnia, runny nose, sweating, and yawning</li>
<li>Late symptoms: abdominal cramping, diarrhea, dilated pupils, goose bumps, nausea, vomiting</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-5-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-5-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_b934746dd2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b934746dd2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be aware that quitting is a long-term process.</b> Methadone withdrawal symptoms typically begin between 24 – 36 hours after the last dose and peak between 96 and 144 hours. While the detox process is usually considered over after five to seven days, milder symptoms may last for weeks, and “abstinence syndrome” — including unease, fatigue, insomnia, and irritability — can last for up to eight months.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-6-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-6-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_17052194ba" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_17052194ba')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Sign up with an inpatient program if possible.</b> Inpatient programs take less time and are up to four times as effective at achieving complete withdrawal.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup> Check <a class="external text" href="http://www.opiateaddictionresource.com/treatment/methadone_clinic_directory" rel="nofollow">here</a> to find a clinic near you.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-7-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-7-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_da489bf083" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_da489bf083')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Reduce methadone use gradually.</b> There are two methods typically used: tapering the amount of methadone used or substituting buprenorphine and tapering or maintaining. Long-term maintenance with buprenorphine, accompanied by counseling and support groups, has been shown to produce the best rate of success.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Rapid detox programs using naltrexone to induce withdrawal can shorten peak withdrawal symptoms to two to three days, but there is no evidence regarding the rates of long-term abstinence for such programs.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Rapid detox under anesthesia should be avoided. It does not improve long-term results and carries a significant risk of death due to pulmonary edema (fluid in the lungs).<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Maintenance on naltrexone is another option. It blocks the nerve receptors that opiates use, meaning that users of naltrexone will be unable to get high on opiates; however, relapse rates are very high for naltrexone treatments.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-8-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-8-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_3e2d57f3fe" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3e2d57f3fe')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Taper with methadone.</b> There are two methods of tapering: a relatively quick method and a more recently prescribed long term method. In both cases, clonidine is often given to help reduce the symptoms of withdrawal.

<ul>
<li>The more traditional tapering method usually takes five to seven weeks. Patients first rapidly reduce their use to 30 mg per day before beginning tapering at a typical rate of 5 mg per week.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Some clinics now recommend a more drawn-out tapering over six months to a year. The dose is reduced by 5 mg every three to 14 days, and then even more slowly after reaching 20 mg.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-9.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_d421ed00b0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d421ed00b0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-9.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Maintain or taper with buprenorphine-naxolone (Subuxone).</b> Buprenorphine maintenance has been shown to be more effective than simply quitting methadone, while tapering with buprenoprhine is just as effective as tapering with methadone, and helps withdrawal symptoms to fade more quickly.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup> Patients must first reduce their methadone use to 40 mg/day for a week before beginning to substitute buprenorphine for methadone. Starting 36 hours after the last dose of methadone, the oral drug buprenorphine can be used to reduce symptoms of withdrawal.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Initial dose is 2 – 4 mg of buprenorphine. If that is tolerated, a second 2 – 4 mg does is given an hour later, and then 4 mg six to eight hours later, for a total day one dose of 8 –12 mg.</li>
<li>A dose of 12 – 16 mg is reached by day two or three and should suppress most symptoms of withdrawal from methadone, with additional symptoms treated by clonidine.</li>
<li>Once the patient’s withdrawal symptoms are stabilized, buprenorphine can be continued as a long-term maintenance drug, or can be tapered off over two to three weeks.</li>
<li>Once you have been weaned off methadone, your primary care provider may also be able to prescribe another form of buprenorphine (Butrans) which is available in patch or oral form.</li>
</ul>
</div>

<a class="anchor" name="Staying_Off_Methadone_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Staying_Off_Methadone">Staying Off Methadone</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-10.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-10.jpg" height="546" id="img_0a40d7807b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0a40d7807b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-10.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get counseling.</b> Your doctor or the clinic you are visiting will be able to put you in touch with an experienced opiate-withdrawal counselor. Whether it is one-on-one, group, or in a family setting, counseling in conjunction with buprenorphine maintenance or detox has been shown to be much more effective than maintenance or detox alone.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-11.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_82541a8cd6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_82541a8cd6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-11.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Join a support group.</b> Support groups like Narcotics Anonymous or SMART Recovery can be extremely helpful for the recovering patient. One study found that recovering patients attending NA and AA programs had an 81% abstinence rate, compared to a 26% abstinence rate among non-attendees.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Don't force yourself to go through the pain of methadone withdrawal alone. There are thousands of other recovering patients just like you, who can not only give you advice and support, but who draw inspiration <i>from</i> you.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-12.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_bc5c4ab5f3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_bc5c4ab5f3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-12.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use clonidine or lofexidine to treat lingering withdrawal symptoms.</b><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup> While clonidine is not as effective as buprenorphine during detox, it is useful in reducing lingering flu-like symptoms such as anxiety, agitation, muscle aches, sweating, runny nose, and cramping, all of which may last up to eight months. Lofexidine is a drug with a similar pathway, recently approved in the UK, which can reduce symptoms with fewer side effects.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-13.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_d42aa5ce36" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d42aa5ce36')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-13.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Ask your doctor about using trazodone, zaleplon or zolpidem to treat insomnia.</b> Insomnia is a common symptom of withdrawal from methadone. Zaleplon and zolpidem work like benzodiazepines such as clonazepam, but without the same withdrawal symptoms.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup> Trazodone is an antidepressant that regulates serotonin levels, thereby aiding sleep.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=14996" href="#/Image:Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/36/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-14.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_7efe44c5e6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7efe44c5e6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Withdraw from Methadone Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/36/Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-14.jpg/aid14996-v4-728px-Withdraw-from-Methadone-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Treat the other lingering symptoms of withdrawal.</b> Muscle cramps, diarrhea, nausea, and flu-like symptoms are most likely during detox, but such symptoms can linger for weeks. Aches and diarrhea can be treated with over-the-counter medications such as ibuprofen (Advil) and bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol). Your doctor may prescribe prochlorperazine (Compazine) or ondansetron (Zofran) for nausea.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="123810" data-caid="124683" data-cqid="123827" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="438794" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="3" data-votes_up="24">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I have been prescribed methadone by my doctor for approximately 15 years. Are the withdrawal symptoms the same as they would be for someone who has been on it a shorter time?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Because the body grows accustomed to the chemical, those in long-term treatment metabolize methadone differently than someone seeking immediate maintenance, and withdrawal can be more severe.  Our bodies replace some endorphins with it, and it blocks certain pain receptors in the brain.  You'll need to taper off more slowly; consider split-dosing, taking 2/3 in the morning and 1/3 at night to fight insomnia.  Once you've grown accustomed to this dose, bump down.  </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>3</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>24</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="207565" data-caid="208438" data-cqid="207582" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="610547" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="7">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How bad will my withdrawal from 4 mgs. be?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Many factors will influence your level of withdrawal, so it's impossible to say. These include the length of time at that current dose, your metabolism, how long you've been taking methadone, etc.</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="264615" data-caid="265488" data-cqid="264632" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1638461" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="5">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Am I going off methadone too slow? I was taking 100 mg, I'm going down 2 mg every 2 weeks, stopping during the summer months. Now I am reducing 1 mg every 2 weeks.</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">There really isn't a "too slow" way of tapering. I am tapering in a similar way. Just do what's comfortable for you.</div>

<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="95877" data-caid="96750" data-cqid="95894" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="440884" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="8" data-votes_up="28">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">My son is on his last week of methadone after a 6 month withdrawal process. He is experiencing a lot of crying and is very emotional. Is this normal and how long will these effects -- along with his flu-like symptoms -- continue?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Perhaps he is coming down too quickly. Those kinds of symptoms are on the severe side, for it being his last week. Consult a different physician, but perhaps he should up his dose and wean himself more slowly.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

title: How to Withdraw from Methadone
content_html:
Consider why you are quitting methadone. If you are taking methadone as a maintenance drug to aid in recovering from an opiate addiction, you are probably better off sticking with it. Methadone maintenance has no significant negative health effects, and patients who remain on methadone show gradual but steady improvements in health and functioning, while those who quit worsen in both aspects and have a much higher tendency to relapse into opiate use.[2]
Speak with an addiction specialist. You will need both medical and psychological support to get off of methadone. It is important to note that not all doctors are able to prescribe withdrawal drugs like suboxone, because it requires a special training and approval from the government, such as the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) in the Unites States. Physicians with the proper training can tailor a withdrawal program to suit your needs and prescribe appropriate withdrawal drugs.
Set up a support network of friends and family. Quitting methadone is not easy. You will suffer withdrawal symptoms, and you will need to either carefully reduce your methadone intake over time or take medications regularly to substitute for methadone. Especially if you are quitting in an out-patient setting, it is extremely helpful to have friends and family who can hold you accountable and remind you to stay on course.
Do not try to quit “cold turkey.” The symptoms of methadone withdrawal are painful enough that quitting suddenly is simply not realistic. They typically begin within 30 hours of last methadone exposure and include:[3][4]
  • Early symptoms: agitation, anxiety, muscle aches, insomnia, runny nose, sweating, and yawning
  • Late symptoms: abdominal cramping, diarrhea, dilated pupils, goose bumps, nausea, vomiting
Be aware that quitting is a long-term process. Methadone withdrawal symptoms typically begin between 24 – 36 hours after the last dose and peak between 96 and 144 hours. While the detox process is usually considered over after five to seven days, milder symptoms may last for weeks, and “abstinence syndrome” — including unease, fatigue, insomnia, and irritability — can last for up to eight months.[5]
Sign up with an inpatient program if possible. Inpatient programs take less time and are up to four times as effective at achieving complete withdrawal.[6] Check here to find a clinic near you.
Reduce methadone use gradually. There are two methods typically used: tapering the amount of methadone used or substituting buprenorphine and tapering or maintaining. Long-term maintenance with buprenorphine, accompanied by counseling and support groups, has been shown to produce the best rate of success.[7]
  • Rapid detox programs using naltrexone to induce withdrawal can shorten peak withdrawal symptoms to two to three days, but there is no evidence regarding the rates of long-term abstinence for such programs.[8]
  • Rapid detox under anesthesia should be avoided. It does not improve long-term results and carries a significant risk of death due to pulmonary edema (fluid in the lungs).[9]
  • Maintenance on naltrexone is another option. It blocks the nerve receptors that opiates use, meaning that users of naltrexone will be unable to get high on opiates; however, relapse rates are very high for naltrexone treatments.
Taper with methadone. There are two methods of tapering: a relatively quick method and a more recently prescribed long term method. In both cases, clonidine is often given to help reduce the symptoms of withdrawal.
  • The more traditional tapering method usually takes five to seven weeks. Patients first rapidly reduce their use to 30 mg per day before beginning tapering at a typical rate of 5 mg per week.[10]
  • Some clinics now recommend a more drawn-out tapering over six months to a year. The dose is reduced by 5 mg every three to 14 days, and then even more slowly after reaching 20 mg.[11]
Maintain or taper with buprenorphine-naxolone (Subuxone). Buprenorphine maintenance has been shown to be more effective than simply quitting methadone, while tapering with buprenoprhine is just as effective as tapering with methadone, and helps withdrawal symptoms to fade more quickly.[12] Patients must first reduce their methadone use to 40 mg/day for a week before beginning to substitute buprenorphine for methadone. Starting 36 hours after the last dose of methadone, the oral drug buprenorphine can be used to reduce symptoms of withdrawal.[13]
  • Initial dose is 2 – 4 mg of buprenorphine. If that is tolerated, a second 2 – 4 mg does is given an hour later, and then 4 mg six to eight hours later, for a total day one dose of 8 –12 mg.
  • A dose of 12 – 16 mg is reached by day two or three and should suppress most symptoms of withdrawal from methadone, with additional symptoms treated by clonidine.
  • Once the patient’s withdrawal symptoms are stabilized, buprenorphine can be continued as a long-term maintenance drug, or can be tapered off over two to three weeks.
  • Once you have been weaned off methadone, your primary care provider may also be able to prescribe another form of buprenorphine (Butrans) which is available in patch or oral form.
Get counseling. Your doctor or the clinic you are visiting will be able to put you in touch with an experienced opiate-withdrawal counselor. Whether it is one-on-one, group, or in a family setting, counseling in conjunction with buprenorphine maintenance or detox has been shown to be much more effective than maintenance or detox alone.[14]
Join a support group. Support groups like Narcotics Anonymous or SMART Recovery can be extremely helpful for the recovering patient. One study found that recovering patients attending NA and AA programs had an 81% abstinence rate, compared to a 26% abstinence rate among non-attendees.[15]
  • Don't force yourself to go through the pain of methadone withdrawal alone. There are thousands of other recovering patients just like you, who can not only give you advice and support, but who draw inspiration from you.
Use clonidine or lofexidine to treat lingering withdrawal symptoms.[16] While clonidine is not as effective as buprenorphine during detox, it is useful in reducing lingering flu-like symptoms such as anxiety, agitation, muscle aches, sweating, runny nose, and cramping, all of which may last up to eight months. Lofexidine is a drug with a similar pathway, recently approved in the UK, which can reduce symptoms with fewer side effects.[17]
Ask your doctor about using trazodone, zaleplon or zolpidem to treat insomnia. Insomnia is a common symptom of withdrawal from methadone. Zaleplon and zolpidem work like benzodiazepines such as clonazepam, but without the same withdrawal symptoms.[18] Trazodone is an antidepressant that regulates serotonin levels, thereby aiding sleep.[19]
Treat the other lingering symptoms of withdrawal. Muscle cramps, diarrhea, nausea, and flu-like symptoms are most likely during detox, but such symptoms can linger for weeks. Aches and diarrhea can be treated with over-the-counter medications such as ibuprofen (Advil) and bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol). Your doctor may prescribe prochlorperazine (Compazine) or ondansetron (Zofran) for nausea.[20]
